It’s not that I don’t have anything to write about, it’s that I have too much to write about, which I will confess is worse than having too little.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text="Living In The Now Use It To Enrich Your Life" font_container="tag:h3|font_size:30px|text_align:left|line_height:40px" use_theme_fonts="yes"][vc_column_text]It is Sunday night and I find myself sitting in my usual location preparing to write the next post on Life of an Architect … except I am experiencing a problem that is making this particular post difficult to write. It’s not that I don’t have anything to write about, it’s that I have too much to write about, which I will confess is worse than having too little.

I have been out of the office for almost two weeks – which rarely-to-never happens. I attended the American Institute of Architects National Convention in New York for a week and then immediately after I rolled into a week-long vacation in Maine. I’ve never been to Maine before and since it was geographically convenient, it seemed like the right time to go. [vc_row css=".vc_custom_1539515690511{padding-top: 30px !important;padding-bottom: 80px !important;}"][vc_column][vc_custom_heading text="Our Thoughts" font_container="tag:h4|font_size:16px|text_align:center|line_height:24px" letter_spacing="2" use_theme_fonts="yes"][vc_custom_heading text="Life of an Architect – The
Inevitable has Arrived" font_container="tag:h1|font_size:60px|text_align:center|line_height:1.4em" text_resize="yes" text_minimum="34" use_theme_fonts="yes" hide_md="cesis_hidden-md" hide_sm="cesis_hidden-sm"][vc_custom_heading text="Life of an Architect – The Inevitable has Arrived" font_container="tag:h1|font_size:34px|text_align:center|line_height:1.4em" use_theme_fonts="yes" hide_lg="cesis_hidden-lg"][cesis_line_divider height="6" width="102" color="#bedfea" margin_bottom="73"][vc_single_image image="71" img_size="full"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="2/3" css=".vc_custom_1539772610005{padding-left: 120px !important;}" offset="vc_hidden-sm vc_hidden-xs"][vc_custom_heading text="It is Sunday night and I find myself sitting in my usual location preparing to write the next post on Life of an Architect" font_container="tag:h4|font_size:22px|text_align:left|line_height:1.5" use_theme_fonts="yes"][vc_column_text]It is Sunday night and I find myself sitting in my usual location preparing to write the next post on Life of an Architect … except I am experiencing a problem that is making this particular post difficult to write. It’s not that I don’t have anything to write about, it’s that I have too much to write about, which I will confess is worse than having too little.[/vc_column_text][vc_custom_heading text="Living In The Now Use It To Enrich Your Life" font_container="tag:h3|font_size:30px|text_align:left|line_height:40px" use_theme_fonts="yes"][vc_column_text]It is Sunday night and I find myself sitting in my usual location preparing to write the next post on Life of an Architect … except I am experiencing a problem that is making this particular post difficult to write. It’s not that I don’t have anything to write about, it’s that I have too much to write about, which I will confess is worse than having too little.

I have been out of the office for almost two weeks – which rarely-to-never happens. I attended the American Institute of Architects National Convention in New York for a week and then immediately after I rolled into a week-long vacation in Maine. I’ve never been to Maine before and since it was geographically convenient, it seemed like the right time to go. Also, it has been hot as Hades in Dallas lately and I wanted needed a break from the heat.[/vc_column_text][vc_single_image image="69" img_size="full" overflow="yes" max_width="1245" max_height="750"][vc_custom_heading text="Living In The Now Use It To Enrich Your Life" font_container="tag:h3|font_size:30px|text_align:left|line_height:40px" use_theme_fonts="yes"][vc_column_text]I have been out of the office for almost two weeks – which rarely-to-never happens. I’ve never been to Maine before and since it was geographically convenient, it seemed like the right time to go.
